context:
<Summary source="https://www.easyofficepools.com/masters-field-listed-by-world-ranking-and-odds-to-win/">
**Disclaimer:** The article content is largely incomplete due to what appears to be unrendered template/dynamic data. The actual golfer names, world rankings, and odds are represented by placeholder variables (e.g., `{{d.golfer}}`, `{{d.rnk}}`, `{{d.odds_numerator}}`) rather than real data, meaning the underlying dataset did not load or render properly during extraction.

---

## Summary

The article from **Easyofficepools** is intended to provide a comprehensive, sortable list of the **2026 Masters Tournament field**, organized by **Official World Golf Ranking (OWGR)** and **betting odds**. Key features described include:

- **Last updated:** Tuesday, February 17th, 2026
- The field list is updated **weekly** to reflect new qualifiers, updated OWGR positions, and current odds
- The resource is designed to assist users in making **Masters golf pool picks**
- Users can **search, filter, sort (by column), and export** the field data
- A **printable version** of the 2026 Masters field is available

However, due to the failure of the dynamic data to render, **no actual golfer names, rankings, or odds are visible** in the extracted content. The number of qualified golfers is also unrendered (`{{data.length}}`).

This article would otherwise be a useful reference for identifying the full field and associated odds, but the extracted version provides no actionable data.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://golfweek.usatoday.com/story/sports/golf/majors/2025/07/24/golf-odds-2026-scottie-scheffler-favorite-masters-all-majors/85353583007/">
## Summary: Scottie Scheffler Favored for All 2026 Majors (Golfweek)

### Key Facts
- Scottie Scheffler won his **fourth major championship** at the 2025 British Open at Royal Portrush, winning by four shots
- He also won the **2025 PGA Championship**, capturing two of the four majors in 2025
- A 2026 U.S. Open win would complete a **career Grand Slam** for Scheffler, joining Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus, Tiger Woods, and Rory McIlroy

### Betting Odds (BetMGM, as of July 22)
**2026 Masters odds:**
| Golfer | Odds |
|--------|------|
| Scottie Scheffler | +400 |
| Rory McIlroy | +550 |
| Ludvig Åberg | +1200 |
| Bryson DeChambeau | +1400 |
| Collin Morikawa | +1400 |
| Jon Rahm | +1400 |
| Xander Schauffele | +1600 |
| Justin Thomas | +2500 |
| Brooks Koepka | +2800 |
| Viktor Hovland | +2800 |

### Named Source Opinion
- **Matt Wall, BetMGM senior trader** (via USA Today Sports): Scheffler's Masters price was shortened from +500 to +400 following his British Open win, with potential for further shortening. Wall noted comparisons to Tiger Woods are appropriate and that early betting action favors Scheffler to win all four 2026 majors (+25000).
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://sports.betmgm.com/en/blog/pga/masters-odds-to-win-bm10/">
## Summary: Masters 2026 Odds (BetMGM)

**Source note:** This article is from BetMGM, a sports betting operator, and is explicitly labeled as entertainment content rather than professional betting advice.

### Key Odds & Market Data
- **Scottie Scheffler** is the early favorite at **+275** (implied probability: ~26.67%)
- **Rory McIlroy** (2025 defending champion) is second at **+750**

### Betting Market Activity (as of February 2026)
- Scheffler leads in both **bets received (18.9%)** and **money wagered (31.3%)**
- **Justin Rose** accounts for **10.1% of money** wagered
- **Bryson DeChambeau** accounts for **8% of bets**

### Contextual Notes
- Odds were posted immediately after Rory McIlroy won the 2025 Masters in a playoff over Justin Rose, completing his career Grand Slam
- Scheffler's favoritism is attributed to his **world No. 1 ranking** and **two prior Masters titles**
- McIlroy's future performance is noted as an open question now that the pressure of the career Grand Slam has been resolved
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://sports.betmgm.com/en/blog/pga/masters-odds-to-win-bm10/">
## Summary: Masters 2026 Odds (BetMGM)

**Source note:** This article is from BetMGM, a sports betting operator, and is explicitly labeled as entertainment content rather than professional analysis.

### Key Odds & Market Data
- **Scottie Scheffler** is the early favorite at **+275** (implied probability: ~26.67%)
- **Rory McIlroy** (2025 defending champion) is second at **+750**

### Betting Market Activity (as of February 2026)
- Scheffler leads in both bets taken (**18.9%**) and money wagered (**31.3%**)
- **Justin Rose** accounts for **10.1%** of the money wagered
- **Bryson DeChambeau** accounts for **8%** of bets placed

### Contextual Notes
- McIlroy is noted to have won the 2025 Masters in a **playoff over Justin Rose**, completing the career Grand Slam
- Scheffler finished **fourth in 2025** and holds **two green jackets**
- Scheffler is described as the **world No. 1-ranked player**
- The article speculates that McIlroy may perform differently in future majors now that the "weight of the career Grand Slam" has been lifted
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.sportingnews.com/uk/golf/news/who-will-win-masters-26-latest-betting-odds-favourite-win-predictions-first-major-augusta/717f5175ff06696755c0c146">
## Summary: Sporting News UK – 2026 Masters Betting Odds & Predictions (February 16, 2026)

### Key Facts
- The 2026 Masters is scheduled for **April 9–12** at Augusta National Golf Club, marking the **90th edition** of the tournament.
- **Rory McIlroy won the 2025 Masters** in a playoff against Justin Rose, completing his career Grand Slam after an 11-year major drought.
- **Scottie Scheffler** is the current betting favourite at **3/1** (best price), with some books listing him at **7/2**.
- McIlroy is second favourite at **17/2** (best price with AK Bets).
- **Ludvig Åberg** is third in the betting at **14/1**.
- Scheffler and McIlroy are the **only two players with single-figure odds**.
- **Tiger Woods** is listed at **175/1** (Sky Bet), having not competed since The Open in July 2024 due to two back surgeries and a ruptured Achilles tendon.

### Notable Context
- Scheffler won the Masters in **2022 and 2024**, and also claimed the PGA Championship and The Open in 2025.
- Europe won the **Ryder Cup** on US soil; the top 10 betting list features five Europeans and five Americans.
- McIlroy won 3.5 points from five Ryder Cup matches; Scheffler beat McIlroy in Sunday singles.

### Predictions (from article author, Peter Fitzpatrick)
- Scheffler and McIlroy identified as the clear frontrunners.
- **Justin Rose** (three-time Augusta runner-up) flagged as a notable outside tip.
- Author's pick: **Rory McIlroy**, citing his fearless mindset as defending champion.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.golfmagic.com/tour/us-masters/masters-field-2026">
## Summary: 2026 Masters Field (as of February 18, 2026)

**Source:** GolfMagic, by Ben Smith — *Note: This appears to be a field preview article, not a results piece, so no winner is identified.*

### Key Tournament Details
- **Dates:** April 9–12, 2026 at Augusta National
- **Field size at time of publication:** 86 players (compared to 96 in 2025)

### Defending Champion
- **Rory McIlroy** will defend the green jacket, having defeated Justin Rose in a playoff at the 2025 Masters, completing the career Grand Slam (only the sixth male golfer to do so)

### Notable Contenders Mentioned
- **Scottie Scheffler** – described as world number one
- **Bryson DeChambeau** – described as a LIV Golf recruit
- **Jon Rahm** – former champion
- **Tommy Fleetwood** – boosted by his Tour Championship win in the U.S.
- Others cited: Xander Schauffele, Ludvig Åberg, Collin Morikawa, Justin Thomas, Viktor Hovland, Patrick Cantlay, Hideki Matsuyama, Cameron Young, Brooks Koepka, Patrick Reed

### Tiger Woods Situation
- Woods (age 50) had back surgery in October 2025 and is still recovering
- As of February 17, 2026, Woods stated his 26th Masters appearance was **"not off the table"**

### Notable Field Additions via Expanded Qualifying Criteria
Augusta National expanded qualifying to include winners of several national opens: Chris Gotterup (Scottish Open), Marco Penge (Spanish Open), Naoyuki Kataoka (Japan Open), Tom McKibbin (Hong Kong Open), and Rasmus Neergaard-Petersen (Australian Open)
</Summary>

Query: Provide reports on recent performances, injuries, and betting expectations for Scottie Scheffler, Rory McIlroy, Jon Rahm, Bryson DeChambeau, and other top golfers in the run-up to the April 2026 Masters Tournament at Augusta National in the United States.
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Rory McIlroy's recent comments suggest a new caddie is needed to take his game to the next level**
Rory McIlroy has implied that his current caddie, Harry Diamond, may be hindering his ability to compete with Scottie Scheffler, citing issues with green reading and lack of mid-round intervention. McIlroy admitted that overthinking his putts—particularly after observing others’ shots—cost him a chance to win the 2026 Genesis Invitational, stating he should have trusted his first instinct. He noted that Diamond did not step in to correct this pattern, unlike top caddies such as Ted Scott, who played a pivotal role in Scheffler’s 2024 Paris Olympics gold medal win. According to Scheffler, Scott took over green reading during the back nine on Sunday, enabling a 9-under 62 and six birdies in a row, which secured victory. McIlroy’s past success, including four majors, was achieved with veteran caddie JP Fitzgerald, raising speculation that a caddie change may be necessary for him to reach Scheffler’s elite level. The article was published on February 25, 2026, by Yardbarker.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 25, 2026 10:09 AM
Source:[Yardbarker](https://www.yardbarker.com/golf/articles/rory_mcilroys_recent_comments_suggest_a_new_caddie_is_needed_to_take_his_game_to_the_next_level/s1_17664_43515513)

**World Top 10: McIlroy Closes Gap on Scheffler, Leishman Rises to Sixth**
On February 23, 2026, the Genesis Invitational, a top-tier tournament, significantly impacted the Official World Golf Rankings, reshaping the top ten. Rory McIlroy, the highest-ranked player in the Riviera tournament, finished tied for second after birdieing two holes on the final stretch, earning 33.47321 points and maintaining his second-place ranking, narrowing the gap with Scottie Scheffler, though the difference remains over 8 points. Collin Morikawa, after winning the Pebble Beach Pro-Am, finished tied for seventh, earning 9.20513 points, and retained fifth place. Xander Schauffele also tied for seventh, earning the same points, and rose from 13th to 9th in the world rankings. Scottie Scheffler's streak of 18 consecutive top-10 finishes ended this week as he tied for 12th, earning 6.10188 points. Notably, Hideki Matsuyama fell out of the top ten in the updated rankings.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 25, 2026 02:46 AM
Source:[新浪竞技风暴](https://sports.sina.com.cn/golf/2026-02-25/doc-inhnyupw2454434.shtml)

**Four storylines for the Cognizant Classic: Shane Lowry headlines the weak field**
The 2026 Cognizant Classic, part of the PGA Tour's Florida Swing, is taking place at PGA National Resort in the Palm Beaches. Top players like Scottie Scheffler are absent, resulting in a weaker field, but several compelling storylines remain. The most prominent is Shane Lowry's pursuit of his first solo PGA Tour victory since 2015. Lowry, who last won the 2019 Open Championship and the 2024 Zurich Classic with Rory McIlroy, has shown strong form at PGA National, finishing runner-up and in the top 11 in his last four appearances. At +1600 odds (FanDuel), he is a co-favorite to win, making this event his best opportunity to end a prolonged winless streak. The tournament is scheduled for February 25, 2026.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 25, 2026 12:42 AM
Source:[Yardbarker](https://www.yardbarker.com/golf/articles/four_storylines_for_the_cognizant_classic_shane_lowry_headlines_the_weak_field/s1_13132_43513516)

**PGA Tour 2026: Meet the Golfers Who Have Earned the Most This Year**
The 2026 PGA Tour season is underway and is shaping up to be one of the most exciting in professional golf history, with a total prize pool exceeding $400 million. This substantial prize fund has intensified competition among top players. As of February 24, 2026, Jacob Bridgeman leads the money list with $5.2 million, followed by Collin Morikawa ($4.2 million), Chris Gotterup ($3.6 million), and Scottie Scheffler ($3.4 million). Bridgeman expressed satisfaction with his performance, stating, 'Each tournament is a new opportunity and I'm just trying to stay focused and keep improving.' Gotterup, a standout rookie, emphasized the high level of competition, saying, 'It's a great honor to be on this list and compete with these incredible players.' Other top performers include Min Woo Lee ($2.3 million), Jake Knapp ($2.2 million), Rory McIlroy ($2.1 million), Hideki Matsuyama ($2.1 million), Ryan Gerard ($2.0 million), Kurt Kitayama ($2.0 million), Sepp Straka ($1.9 million), and several emerging talents. The season's diversity is highlighted by rising stars challenging established veterans. The race for the top prize remains fiercely competitive, with fans eagerly anticipating each tournament.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 24, 2026 08:58 PM
Source:[SAPO](https://sapo.pt/artigo/pga-tour-2026-conheca-os-golfistas-que-mais-ganharam-este-ano-699e12fc441d32e822d81fda)

**PGA Tour pro breaks silence on Rory McIlroy's potential retirement timeline and shares an honest verdict | International Sports News - The Times of India**
PGA Tour professional Joel Dahmen, during a conversation with Trey Wingo, expressed the view that Rory McIlroy, at age 36, may retire from professional golf earlier than previously anticipated. Dahmen noted that McIlroy, having already achieved the career Grand Slam at the 2025 Masters, now has no further career milestones to pursue. With current top golfers like McIlroy and Scottie Scheffler earning tens of millions annually in prize money, bonuses, and endorsements, financial security is achieved much earlier than in past generations. Dahmen believes that this financial independence, combined with the physical toll of modern high-speed swings (185–190 mph vs. older 165 mph), will lead to shorter careers. He predicts that elite players will likely peak and retire in their mid-30s, having accumulated $250 million, settled their families, and fulfilled their ambitions. Dahmen added that this shift is already underway and will become more evident within the next decade. He also referenced the impact of NIL (Name, Image, Likeness) deals in college sports, suggesting that early financial success is altering athlete motivation across sports. According to Dahmen, the traditional drive to play into the Champions Tour era may no longer exist.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 24, 2026 06:44 PM
Source:[The Times of India](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/international-sports/pga-tour-pro-breaks-silence-on-rory-mcilroys-potential-retirement-timeline-and-shares-an-honest-verdict/articleshow/128759933.cms)

**Jacob Bridgeman's breakout win, Tiger Woods' eventful week and the most painful fantasy football punishment ever**
Jacob Bridgeman secured his first PGA Tour victory at the Genesis Invitational, overcoming a seven-shot lead reduction to win by one stroke at Riviera, earning a silver trophy from Tiger Woods. His consistent performance, including four consecutive top-20 finishes to start 2026 and a Tour Championship appearance last year, confirmed his legitimacy. Jeeno Thitikul claimed her most significant career win at the LPGA Honda Thailand in her home country, with emotional support from her mother. Anthony Kim made a remarkable comeback after overcoming injuries, substance abuse, and mental health struggles, winning for the first time in 16 years by defeating Bryson DeChambeau and Jon Rahm, with a touching moment as his daughter greeted him on the 18th green. Scottie Scheffler's 11-month streak of top-10 finishes ended at T-12 after strong performances from Cam Young and Tommy Fleetwood, though his Thursday struggles (73, 72, 74 in last three opening rounds) raised questions about his start consistency. A viral fantasy football punishment video showed a player suffering a painful golf ball impact to the midsection, highlighting the high-stakes nature of fantasy sports. The PGA Tour continues with the Cognizant Classic at PGA National, where bucket hat wearers have won the past two years. Random bets include Joel Dahmen winning (80-to-1) and wearing a bucket hat (locked). Tiger Woods had an eventful week, posing with girlfriend Vanessa Trump at the Ben Hogan statue and giving a pep talk to the Lakers, who lost to the Celtics. Rory McIlroy’s quote about a $600,000 bonus was noted as a highlight. Justin Thomas returned from back surgery in a TGL win and will play at Bay Hill next week. Dr. Pepper Zero is now available at Costco, praised as a top diet soda alternative.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 24, 2026 05:16 PM
Source:[GolfDigest.com](https://www.golfdigest.com/story/jacob-bridgeman-tiger-woods-genesis-invitational-painful-fantasy-football-golf-punishment-the-grind)

**The moment at Riviera that could help Rory McIlroy at Augusta**
Rory McIlroy may be poised for a strong performance at the 2026 Masters, as signs from his recent play at Pebble Beach and Riviera suggest he is regaining elite form. According to Gary Williams of 5 Clubs, McIlroy’s 64 in the final round at Pebble Beach—bogey-free—highlighted his improved shot-making, particularly his ability to flight shots with precision, execute low bullet-like trajectories, and control ball roll on soft fairways. These skills were notably evident on the 18th hole, where he consistently placed shots on the spine of the fairway, allowing them to bleed out to the right. Williams also pointed to McIlroy’s pivotal tee shot at the 17th during the playoff at The Players Championship as a turning point in his season. McIlroy currently leads the PGA Tour in strokes gained approach, surpassing Scottie Scheffler, and came close to overtaking Bridgeman in the final round at Pacific Palisades, missing only by a fraction. With Scheffler not yet at peak form and McIlroy freed from the pressure of needing to win, his path to a sixth major title in 2026 appears increasingly viable.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 24, 2026 04:53 PM
Source:[Yardbarker](https://www.yardbarker.com/golf/articles/the_moment_at_riviera_that_could_help_rory_mcilroy_at_augusta/s1_17664_43511884)

**Rory McIlroy shows true colours in £1.3m payday snub after 'extra money' comment - The Mirror**
Rory McIlroy has opted to skip the Cognizant Classic, choosing instead to play a round at Augusta National with his father, Gerry, and National Chairman Fred Ridley. This decision comes after McIlroy finished tied for second at the Genesis Invitational, earning £1.3 million—just one stroke behind champion Jacob Bridgeman. Although he acknowledged that finishing joint-second earned him an additional £445,000 compared to a tied-third finish, McIlroy downplayed the financial impact, stating, 'It probably earned me an extra 400, 500 grand, so it's fine.' He reflected on his performance, admitting he overthought his putts, particularly on the front nine, and failed to trust his instincts, saying, 'I was reading too much into them... I was almost just giving them too much thought and not going with my first instinct, and that sort of cost me.' McIlroy, the defending Masters champion and a two-time Players Championship winner (2019, 2025), expressed confidence in his game, noting it is 'in really good shape' and 'much better than it did in Dubai.' His upcoming events include the Arnold Palmer Invitational and The Players Championship, where he aims to build on recent progress.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 24, 2026 04:30 PM
Source:[Mirror](https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/golf/rory-mcilroy-golf-pga-snub-36774640)

**Scottie Scheffler's first-round struggles prove capability of world No. 1 - CBS Sports**
Scottie Scheffler, the world No. 1 on the PGA Tour, has struggled in the first round of tournaments during the 2026 season, ranking 116th in Round 1 scoring average despite leading the tour in overall scoring average. At the Genesis Invitational, Scheffler started 5 over through his first 10 holes, made an 8-foot par putt on the 36th hole just to avoid missing the cut, and finished T12 alongside Jordan Spieth—despite his slow start. This performance continued a pattern: he opened with a 73 at the WM Phoenix Open, finishing one stroke short of a playoff, and a 72 at the Pebble Beach Pro-Am, where he closed with a 63 and three final-round eagles, falling two strokes short of Collin Morikawa. Scheffler has won twice at player-hosted signature events (Arnold Palmer Invitational and Jack Nicklaus Invitational), but remains without a victory at the Tiger Woods-hosted event. His ability to rally—playing his final 62 holes in 16 under par at the Genesis Invitational—has highlighted his resilience, with Rory McIlroy noting the growing importance of these player-hosted invitationals. Despite early struggles, Scheffler remains the favorite across all four majors: 3-1 at the Masters, 19/5 at the PGA Championship, 16/5 at the U.S. Open, and 5-1 at The Open, per FanDuel. His comebacks underscore his elite capability, proving that his dominance is not limited to strong starts but also extends to overcoming adversity.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 23, 2026 07:49 PM
Source:[CBS Sports](https://www.cbssports.com/golf/news/scottie-scheffler-first-round-struggles/)

**Cognizant Classic 2026 field: 5 big-name golfers missing ft. Rory McIlroy**
The 2026 Cognizant Classic, a PGA Tour event scheduled to begin on Thursday, February 26, and conclude on Sunday, March 1, will feature a full field but exclude five prominent golfers. Rory McIlroy, who finished T14 at the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am and tied for second at the Genesis Invitational, will not participate. Scottie Scheffler, the World No. 1, who recorded a T3 at the WM Phoenix Open and a T4 at the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am, is also absent. Xander Schauffele missed the cut at the Farmers Insurance Open and finished T41 at the WM Phoenix Open, and will not play. Viktor Hovland, who finished T41 at the Genesis Invitational after a strong start, will miss the event. Patrick Cantlay, who had a T13 at The American Express and a T37 at the Genesis Invitational, will also be absent. The tournament is set to take place at the PGA Tour's regular venue, though the specific location is not mentioned in the article.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 23, 2026 12:49 PM
Source:[Sportskeeda](https://www.sportskeeda.com/golf/cognizant-classic-2026-field-5-big-name-golfers-missing-ft-rory-mcilroy)

**Scottie Scheffler's Personal Record Drops Back to Zero After Not-So-Good Outing**
Scottie Scheffler's streak of top-10 finishes in his last 18 tournaments ended at the Genesis Invitational, where he finished tied for 12th. After a slow start with a 5-over-par performance on his first 10 holes on Thursday, Scheffler rebounded with rounds of 66 on Saturday and 65 on Sunday, entering the final hole at even par. On the 18th hole, he missed a 21-foot birdie putt that would have moved him into the top 10, ending his streak. Despite the setback, Scheffler stated he remains focused on the present and does not set long-term goals, emphasizing his preparation for the season. The tournament was won by Jacob Bridgeman, a 26-year-old former Clemson player, who closed with a 18-under-par total of 266, securing his first PGA Tour victory by one shot over Rory McIlroy and Kurt Kitayama. Bridgeman led by six shots entering the final round and extended it to seven at one point before carding a 1-over 72 on Sunday to hold on for the win.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 23, 2026 12:35 PM
Source:[Yardbarker](https://www.yardbarker.com/golf/articles/scottie_schefflers_personal_record_drops_back_to_zero_after_not_so_good_outing/s1_17768_43506335)

**Rory McIlroy's Genesis Invitational behavior speaks volumes about Bryson DeChambeau dynamic**
Rory McIlroy's behavior at the 2026 Genesis Invitational has sparked speculation about his relationship with Bryson DeChambeau, a rivalry that has dominated golf headlines over the past two seasons. McIlroy defeated DeChambeau at the 2024 US Open, but DeChambeau avenged the loss by winning the 2025 Masters, where McIlroy reportedly barely spoke to him during the final round, citing focus on winning the Green Jacket. At the Genesis Invitational, McIlroy played alongside Jacob Bridgeman, who held a six-shot lead heading into the final round; McIlroy closed the gap to one shot on the 18th hole. The contrast in McIlroy’s interaction with Bridgeman versus DeChambeau has drawn attention, raising questions about the nature of their professional relationship.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 23, 2026 12:29 PM
Source:[Yardbarker](https://www.yardbarker.com/golf/articles/rory_mcilroys_genesis_invitational_behavior_speaks_volumes_about_bryson_dechambeau_dynamic/s1_17664_43506324)

**'My game is in really good shape' - Rory McIlroy confident as Masters countdown begins with second-place finish in LA**
Rory McIlroy finished second at the Genesis Invitational at Riviera Country Club, marking his 13th PGA Tour runner-up finish and signaling strong form ahead of the Masters, which he will defend in 44 days. Despite a six-shot deficit to Jacob Bridgeman, who claimed his maiden PGA Tour title with a one-over 72 to finish at 18-under-par, McIlroy posted a four-under 67 in the final round, tying for second with Kurt Kitayama. McIlroy noted his game is 'in really good shape,' citing only three bogeys in 72 holes and improved performance compared to his earlier struggles in Dubai. He expressed frustration over missed opportunities on the front nine and back nine of the tournament, particularly on the first 27 holes, where he failed to capitalize on chances. However, he described the West Coast Swing as 'really positive,' with a week off to fine-tune his game before the Arnold Palmer Invitational and The Players Championship. Bridgeman, who overcame a seven-shot lead to a one-shot margin on the final hole, made a par putt from three feet, nine inches after McIlroy's 30-footer on 18, and was celebrated by tournament host Tiger Woods, who said, 'You've got one on me,' referencing his own failure to win at Riviera. Bridgeman earned $4 million, a Genesis GV80 coupe, a three-year PGA Tour exemption, and a Masters debut. World number one Scottie Scheffler finished tied for 12th on 11-under, ending his top-10 streak at 18 consecutive events. Shane Lowry finished tied for 24th on seven-under with a final-round 67, highlighted by seven birdies, including three in his last four holes.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 23, 2026 07:56 AM
Source:[Irish Independent](https://www.independent.ie/sport/golf/my-game-is-in-really-good-shape-rory-mcilroy-confident-as-masters-countdown-begins-with-second-place-finish-in-la/a1815064864.html)

**Jacob Bridgeman hangs on to claim first PGA Tour title at Riviera**
Jacob Bridgeman claimed his first PGA Tour title at the Genesis Invitational on February 22, 2026, at Riviera Country Club, finishing one shot ahead of Rory McIlroy and Kurt Kitayama with a 18-under-par total of 266. Bridgeman started the day with a six-shot lead, which expanded to seven after birdies on the first and third holes, but he recorded no further birdies, carding a one-over 72. His lead was reduced to one after a bogey from a greenside bunker at the 16th, and he narrowly made par from a bunker at the 17th. At the 18th, he hit his approach to 20 feet and made the crucial par putt to secure victory. Bridgeman admitted he felt nervous, especially after a 'sketchy' five-footer for bogey on 16. Rory McIlroy, who started six shots behind, shot a four-under 67 with five birdies, including a hole-out from a bunker, and finished tied for second. Kurt Kitayama, 33, posted a seven-under 64 with eight birdies to finish solo second. Adam Scott, the 2020 Riviera winner, shot an eight-under 63 to finish fourth at 268. McIlroy praised Bridgeman’s composure under pressure, noting the difficulty of closing out tournaments. World No. 1 Scottie Scheffler, despite a six-under 65, saw his streak of 18 consecutive top-10 finishes end with a tie for 12th at 11-under. Meanwhile, Tiger Woods, 50, hinted at a possible return to professional golf at the upcoming Masters, saying 'There is' when asked if he could play, though he has not competed since the 2024 Open Championship due to disc replacement and Achilles surgery.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 23, 2026 06:40 AM
Source:[The Straits Times](https://www.straitstimes.com/sport/golf/jacob-bridgeman-hangs-on-to-claim-first-pga-tour-title-at-riviera)

**Scottie Scheffler, Rory McIlroy Lead 2026 Masters Odds Just Under 2 Months Out - Bleacher Nation**
As the 2026 Masters approaches with less than two months remaining, DraftKings futures odds reflect Scottie Scheffler as the clear favorite at +300, with Rory McIlroy second at +600. Scheffler has recorded four consecutive top-10 finishes at Augusta National and has won two majors in 2025, including the PGA Championship and The Open Championship. McIlroy, the defending champion after his 2025 playoff victory over Justin Rose, completed his career Grand Slam and is viewed as a strong fit for Augusta. Behind them, players like Jon Rahm and Bryson DeChambeau are listed at +1000, while Tommy Fleetwood, Xander Schauffele, Collin Morikawa, and Ludvig Aberg follow in the +1500 to +2600 range. Mid-tier options such as Justin Rose (+3000), Hideki Matsuyama (+3500), Jordan Spieth (+4000), and Brooks Koepka (+4000) offer value for multi-player bets. Longer shots like Patrick Cantlay (+5000), Will Zalatoris (+5500), and Akshay Bhatia (+6000) are considered potential sleepers. Key historical trends show that 9 of the last 11 Masters winners had played in at least three Masters prior, 8 had top-5 finishes, and all were in the world top 25. Greens-in-regulation performance has also been a recurring factor. The article advises bettors to act early on mid-tier players to lock in favorable odds and to practice responsible gambling by allocating 10–15% of their betting budget to futures and seeking help via the National Council on Problem Gambling at 1-800-522-4700 or ncpgambling.org.

**Phil Mickelson Makes Bold Declaration About Anthony Kim's Future That Scottie Scheffler & Co. Won't Like**
Anthony Kim, a 40-year-old golfer, won the 2026 LIV Golf Adelaide event by defeating top players Jon Rahm and Bryson DeChambeau, marking his first LIV Golf victory and a career-best performance. This win, achieved after a 9-under 63 in the final round, propelled him up 647 spots on the Official World Golf Ranking (OWGR), placing him under the 200th mark—within the top-200. Phil Mickelson praised Kim's achievement in a tweet, calling it 'one of the best stories in sports' and stating that Kim 'deserves the opportunity' to compete in the majors, even suggesting he could challenge Scottie Scheffler and other top players. While Kim currently qualifies for major championships via OWGR ranking, he must reach the top-50 by April 2026 to play in the 2026 Masters Tournament. With three LIV Golf events remaining before Augusta, Kim will need strong finishes to secure his spot. His rise since joining 4Aces GC has been dramatic, both in performance and ranking, and his journey has inspired many, according to Mickelson.

Lifetime invitations are granted to past Masters champions: Rory McIlroy, Scottie Scheffler, Jon Rahm, Hideki Matsuyama, Dustin Johnson, Tiger Woods, Patrick Reed, Sergio Garcia, Danny Willett, Jordan Spieth, Bubba Watson, Adam Scott, Charl Schwartzel, Phil Mickelson, Angel Cabrera, Zach Johnson, Mike Weir, Vijay Singh, Jose Maria Olazabal, and Fred Couples. Spaun, Bryson DeChambeau, Wyndham Clark, and Matt Fitzpatrick. British Open champions (within five years) are Brian Harman, Cameron Smith, and Collin Morikawa. Players Championship winners from the last three years will be confirmed on March 15, 2026. Amateur qualifiers include NCAA champion Michael LaSasso, U.S. Amateur champion Mason Howell and runner-up Jackson Herrington, British Amateur champion Ethan Fang, U.S. Mid-Amateur champion Brandon Holtz, Asia-Pacific Amateur champion Fifa Laopakdee, and Latin America Amateur champion Mateo Pulcini. **Scottie Scheffler's latest decision could make 2026 even tougher for his rivals**
Scottie Scheffler, a dominant force on the PGA Tour since February 2022 with 19 PGA Tour wins and four major championships, is positioning himself for even greater success in 2026. Despite a slow start to his 2025 season—partly due to an injury that caused him to miss The Sentry and delayed his rhythm—Scheffler has entered The American Express in La Quinta, California, as part of a strategic early-season buildup. This move aims to sharpen his game before major tournaments intensify in February. His improved preparation, including enhanced ball speed and a full preseason, could help him regain peak form quickly. With rivals like Rory McIlroy, Tommy Fleetwood, Xander Schauffele, and LIV Golf stars Bryson DeChambeau and Jon Rahm eyeing challenges in 2026, Scheffler’s early-season decision may give him a competitive edge, potentially setting a strong tone for a historic campaign akin to Tiger Woods’ 2000 season, where Woods won nine times.

**Scottie Scheffler's Grand Slam, Tiger Woods to return and a huge year for LIV Golf in 2026 - The Mirror**
The year 2026 promises major developments in professional golf. Rory McIlroy completed his career Grand Slam by winning the Masters in April, becoming the first European to do so. Scottie Scheffler followed by winning the US PGA and then his third Major at the Open Championship held at Royal Portrush. Scheffler aims to win the US Open at Shinnecock Hills in June, his home Major. Phil Mickelson, now 55, needs only the US Open to complete his career Grand Slam, while Jordan Spieth still needs the US PGA. The PGA Tour and LIV Golf remain in a legal and structural standoff, with LIV Golf planning to expand to 72-hole events and increase field sizes to 57 players. The departure of five-time Major winner Brooks Koepka from LIV Golf is a significant blow, and his future playing destination remains uncertain, possibly involving a ban before rejoining the PGA Tour. LIV must now secure Bryson DeChambeau and other top players. The European Ryder Cup team’s 2023 victory on US soil boosted confidence, with Bob McIntyre finishing second at the 2025 US Open and left-handers historically performing well at Augusta National. Ludvig Aberg, a rising star, has finished second and seventh in his first two Masters appearances. The biggest story could be Tommy Fleetwood, Europe’s top points scorer at Bethpage Black, winning his home Open at Royal Birkdale. Two European players, Sergio Garcia, Ian Poulter, and Lee Westwood, are still appealing bans and fines from joining LIV Golf in 2024; from January 1, 2026, LIV no longer covers these fines. If they lose their appeal, they must pay large fines to remain eligible for the Ryder Cup, with Jon Rahm refusing to pay on principle. Tiger Woods, who has undergone three operations since his last tournament at the 2024 Open, is back in training after turning 50 on December 30, 2025, and is now eligible for the PGA Senior Tour. Woods could complete a Grand Slam of US titles by winning the US Senior Open in July 2026 and may return to the PGA Tour, with a possible appearance at the Genesis Open in February. Behind the scenes, Woods chairs the PGA Tour Future Competition Committee, tasked with designing a streamlined tour for 2027. He is expected to be named captain of the US Ryder Cup team for the 2027 event at Adare Manor, owned by his friend JP McManus, though no official announcement has been made as of December 2025. Woods stated, 'No one's asked me about it,' during his pre-Hero World Challenge interview.

--- Deep Research Analysis ---
Based on current reports as of February 25, 2026, here is a comprehensive overview of the top golfers' form, fitness, and betting markets heading into the April 2026 Masters Tournament at Augusta National.

## Scottie Scheffler (World No. 1)

**Recent Performance:** Scheffler remains the dominant force in golf despite some uncharacteristic early-tournament struggles. His remarkable streak of 18 consecutive top-10 finishes ended at the Genesis Invitational, where he finished T-12 after a final-round 65 narrowly missed moving him into the top 10 [4][7]. He has shown a pattern of slow starts this season—ranking 116th in Round 1 scoring average despite leading the tour in overall scoring [6]. At the Genesis Invitational, he was 5-over through his first 10 holes but rallied to play his final 62 holes in 16-under-par [6]. He has won twice at signature events this season (Arnold Palmer Invitational and Jack Nicklaus Invitational) but remains winless at Tiger Woods-hosted events [6].

**Injury Status:** No injuries reported.

**Masters Betting Expectations:** Scheffler is the clear favorite across all four majors, with Masters odds of +300 (3-1) at DraftKings and FanDuel [6][13]. He has recorded four consecutive top-10 finishes at Augusta National and won two majors in 2025 (PGA Championship and The Open Championship) [13].

## Rory McIlroy (Defending Masters Champion)

**Recent Performance:** McIlroy enters the Masters defense in strong form, having just finished runner-up at the Genesis Invitational at Riviera Country Club, one shot behind Jacob Bridgeman [9][10]. He posted a bogey-free 64 in the final round at Pebble Beach earlier this season and currently leads the PGA Tour in strokes gained approach, surpassing Scheffler [5]. McIlroy has expressed confidence, stating "my game is in really good shape" after making only three bogeys in 72 holes at Riviera [9]. He will skip the Cognizant Classic to focus on his Masters defense, which begins in approximately 44 days [9][11].

**Injury Status:** No injuries reported.

**Masters Betting Expectations:** McIlroy is the second favorite at +600 (6-1) [13]. As the 2025 Masters champion, he completed his career Grand Slam and is viewed as an excellent fit for Augusta National [13]. However, recent reports suggest potential caddie concerns, with McIlroy implying that his current caddie Harry Diamond may be hindering his ability to compete with Scheffler's level, referencing how Ted Scott intervened during Scheffler's Olympic victory [1].

## Jon Rahm

**Recent Performance:** Rahm has been competing on the LIV Golf circuit and recently finished second to Anthony Kim at the LIV Golf Adelaide event in Australia [17]. During that tournament, Rahm shot a nine-under 63 at The Grange Golf Club to take the halfway lead on 13-under-par, making 151 feet of putts with an eagle and seven birdies [18]. He remains a consistent threat in major championships.

**Injury Status:** No injuries reported.

**Masters Betting Expectations:** Rahm is listed at +1000 (10-1) alongside Bryson DeChambeau [13]. He has been named to the European Ryder Cup team as a captain's pick for the 2025 matches at Bethpage Black [20].

## Bryson DeChambeau

**Recent Performance:** DeChambeau faces growing concerns about his final-round performance under pressure. He lost to Anthony Kim at LIV Golf Adelaide, continuing a troubling trend where he has recorded 11 rounds over par in 2025, including six in final rounds [15]. This pattern mirrors his struggles at the 2024 Masters, where he finished six shots worse than his previous three final rounds [15]. Despite winning the 2024 US Open over McIlroy, he has only one LIV Golf win since 2024 [15].

**Injury Status:** No injuries reported.

**Masters Betting Expectations:** DeChambeau is listed at +1000 (10-1) [13]. Phil Mickelson has publicly stated that players like DeChambeau (and Rahm) should be allowed to compete in majors, though their LIV Golf status creates qualifying complications [19].

## Other Top Contenders

**Collin Morikawa:** Currently second on the PGA Tour money list with $4.2 million in earnings [3]. Masters odds at +2600 [13].

**Xander Schauffele:** Listed at +1500 to +2200 for the Masters [13][16].

**Tommy Fleetwood:** Masters odds around +1500 to +2400 [13][16].

**Hideki Matsuyama:** The 2025 Genesis Invitational champion (held at Torrey Pines due to wildfires) is listed at +3500 [13][16].

**Jacob Bridgeman:** The current PGA Tour money leader ($5.2 million) and Genesis Invitational winner has qualified for his first Masters [3][9].

**Anthony Kim:** The remarkable comeback story—Kim won LIV Golf Adelaide with a final-round 63, defeating both Rahm and DeChambeau, and jumped 647 spots in the world rankings [17]. He needs to reach the top-50 by April to qualify for the Masters [17].

**Tiger Woods:** Now 50 years old, Woods has hinted at a possible return to professional golf at the upcoming Masters, stating "There is" when asked if he could play, though he has not competed since the 2024 Open Championship due to disc replacement and Achilles surgery [10].

## Augusta National Course Changes

The club has lengthened the 17th hole (Nandina) by approximately 10 yards to 450 yards total, repositioning the tee markers to increase difficulty [14]. McIlroy has publicly criticized this change as "horrible," noting it forces players to use longer clubs and disrupts the traditional challenge [12].

## Summary of Betting Markets

According to DraftKings and FanDuel as of mid-February 2026:

- **Scottie Scheffler:** +300 (3-1) [13]
- **Rory McIlroy:** +600 (6-1) [13]
- **Jon Rahm:** +1000 (10-1) [13]
- **Bryson DeChambeau:** +1000 (10-1) [13]
- **Tommy Fleetwood:** +1500 [13]
- **Xander Schauffele:** +1500 [13]
- **Ludvig Åberg:** +2600 [13]
- **Collin Morikawa:** +2600 [13]
- **Justin Rose:** +3000 [13]
- **Hideki Matsuyama:** +3500 [13]
- **Jordan Spieth:** +4000 [13]

Historical trends suggest that 9 of the last 11 Masters winners had played in at least three Masters prior, and all were ranked in the world top 25 [13]. With McIlroy seeking to become only the fourth player to win back-to-back Masters (joining Jack Nicklaus, Nick Faldo, and Tiger Woods), and Scheffler chasing his first green jacket since 2024, the 2026 tournament promises significant storylines [11].
